questions.text: Which of the following features can be alleviated by performing surgical correction of VSD in an infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Failure to Thrive

Explanation:

Infants with a large VSD can develop heart failure that leads to poor weight gain and inadequate growth, called failure to thrive.

Surgical correction of VSD aims to repair the structural defect, which reduces strain, improves cardiac function, and prevents pulmonary vascular disease. It can enhance the infant's ability to feed, leading to proper weight gain and relieving the feature of failure to thrive.

Indications of surgery in VSD:

  • Large defects in patients of any age who have persistent symptoms or fail to thrive.

  • Moderate to large defects in infants aged 6 to 12 months with pulmonary hypertension, even if symptoms are managed with medication.

  • Children older than 24 months with a Qp:Qs ratio of >2:1.

  • Supracristal VSDs of any size due to an elevated risk of aortic valve regurgitation.

Contraindications for VSD closure:

  • Severe pulmonary vascular disease that does not respond to pulmonary vasodilator therapy.

Respiratory alkalosis (Option A) is not the main acid-base disturbance in VSD. Large VSDs primarily cause metabolic acidosis (due to CHF), not persistent respiratory alkalosis. If respiratory alkalosis occurs, it is secondary to mild tachypnea and not the primary issue requiring surgical correction.

Surgery does not reliably prevent or treat arrhythmia (Option C) and may sometimes increase the risk of it.

Surgical repair does not alleviate heart block (Option D); rather, it is a potential complication of VSD closure and may occur perioperatively.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with exertional dyspnea and a history of cyanotic spells. On examination, there is clubbing and a harsh systolic murmur heard at the left upper sternal border. Chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tetralogy of Fallot

Explanation: The child presents with cyanotic spells, exertional dyspnea, and clubbing, all classic signs of a cyanotic congenital heart disease.

  • A harsh systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border is most consistent with right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (pulmonary stenosis) in Tetralogy of Fallot.

Components of Tetralogy of Fallot:

  • Pulmonary Stenosis:
    • Narrowing of the pathway from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery, possibly affecting the infundibulum, valve, or main pulmonary artery.
  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD):
    • A large hole between the right and left ventricles, usually misaligned, allowing abnormal blood flow.
  • Overriding Aorta:
    • The aorta is positioned over the septum, receiving blood from both ventricles.
  • Right Ventricular Hypertrophy:
    • Thickening of the right ventricle wall due to the extra effort required to pump blood.

Incorrect Options:

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (Option B): Classically shows a “snowman” or “figure-of-eight” appearance on X-ray, not boot-shaped heart.

Transposition of the Great Arteries (Option C): Chest X-ray may show an “egg-on-a-string” appearance; cyanosis appears in the first days of life, not typically at age 5.

Atrial Septal Defect (Option D): Usually acyanotic; X-ray shows cardiomegaly with increased pulmonary vascular markings, not boot-shaped heart.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a history of cyanosis since infancy. Which of the following is a component of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option B) Infundibular pulmonary stenosis

Explanation:

Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect characterized by four distinct anomalies:

  1. Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): A hole between the right and left ventricles.
  2. Pulmonary Stenosis: Narrowing of the pulmonary outflow tract. This can be subvalvular (infundibular, below the valve), valvular (at the valve), or supravalvular (above the valve). Infundibular pulmonary stenosis is a common and characteristic component.
  3. Overriding Aorta: The aorta (the main artery carrying oxygenated blood to the body) is positioned directly over the VSD, receiving blood from both ventricles.
  4. Right Ventricular Hypertrophy (RVH): The right ventricle thickens due to the increased workload of pumping blood against the narrowed pulmonary artery and into the aorta.

The options provided

  • Inter atrial septal defect (ASD) (Option A ruled out): While an ASD can coexist with TOF (forming Pentalogy of Fallot), it is not a primary component of the classic Tetralogy of Fallot.
  • Infundibular pulmonary stenosis(Option B): This is a core component of Tetralogy of Fallot. The narrowing in the outflow tract of the right ventricle is often in the infundibular region.
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH)(Option C ruled out): In TOF, it's the right ventricle that undergoes hypertrophy due to the increased pressure load. Left ventricular hypertrophy is not a typical feature.
  • Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)(Option D ruled out): TGA is a completely separate and distinct complex congenital heart defect where the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. It is not a component of TOF.

questions.text: In newborns, what is the primary cause of ventriculomegaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Aqueductal stenosis

  • Ventriculomegaly refers to the dilation or enlargement of the cerebral ventricles, which are fluid-filled spaces within the brain. It is a common finding in newborns and can be caused by various underlying conditions. Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns.
  • Aqueductal stenosis is a condition characterized by a narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, a narrow passage that connects the third and fourth ventricles in the brain. When this passage is narrowed or blocked, the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is obstructed, leading to the accumulation of fluid in the ventricles and resulting in ventriculomegaly.

Incorrect Choices

Option A: Arnold-Chiari malformation- Arnold-Chiari malformation refers to a group of structural defects in the brain and spinal cord. It involves a downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the opening at the base of the skull. While it can be associated with hydrocephalus, it is not the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns.

Option B: Dandy-Walker syndrome- Dandy-Walker syndrome is a congenital brain malformation characterized by the enlargement of the fourth ventricle and the presence of a cystic structure in the posterior fossa. While it can cause hydrocephalus, it is not the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns.

Option C: Arachnoid Villi malformation- Arachnoid villi are structures that help drain cerebrospinal fluid from the brain into the bloodstream. Malformation or dysfunction of these structures can lead to impaired CSF drainage and hydrocephalus. However, it is not the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns.

questions.text: Continuous murmur is heard in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA):

  • A continuous (machinery-like) murmur is often heard in PDA. This is due to the persistent connection between the aorta and the pulmonary artery, leading to continuous blood flow during both systole and diastole.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - VSD (Ventricular Septal Defect): VSD typically presents with a holosystolic murmur, not a continuous murmur.

Option C - ASD (Atrial Septal Defect): ASD is associated with a fixed split second heart sound (S2) and a systolic ejection murmur, not a continuous murmur.

Option D - Tetralogy of Fallot: Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by a harsh systolic ejection murmur, not a continuous murmur.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Atrial septal defect

Explanation:

Atrial septal defect is not the component of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

Tetralogy of Fallot

Components of Tetralogy of Fallot:

  • Pulmonary Stenosis: (Option D Ruled Out)
    • Narrowing of the pathway from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery, possibly affecting the infundibulum, valve, or main pulmonary artery.
  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): (Option A Ruled Out)
    • A large hole between the right and left ventricles, usually misaligned, allowing abnormal blood flow.
  • Overriding Aorta:
    • The aorta is positioned over the septum, receiving blood from both ventricles.
  • Right Ventricular Hypertrophy: (Option B Ruled Out)
    • Thickening of the right ventricle wall due to the extra effort required to pump blood.

Clinical features:

  • Cyanosis (central) due to hypoxia; SpO2 <75-85%
  • Clubbing
  • Polycythemia
  • Cyanotic spells

Auscultatory findings:

  • Ejection systolic murmur in the pulmonary area
  • Single S2 (P2 is soft and inaudible)

Chest X-ray:

  • Boot-Shaped Heart or 'Cor en Sabot' appearance = Pulmonary oligemia

questions.text:
Which of the following congenital heart disease presents with split-second heart sounds?


	Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)
	Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)
	Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)
	Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Only 1,2,3 is correct

Explanation:

Congenital heart diseases that can present with split-second heart sounds include:

  • Atrial Septal Defect (ASD): An ASD is a hole in the wall (septum) that separates the two upper chambers of the heart (atria). It can lead to increased blood flow from the left atrium to the right atrium, resulting in more evident splitting of the second heart sound (S2) during auscultation.
  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): A VSD is a hole in the septum between the two lower chambers of the heart (ventricles). Like ASD, it can cause increased blood flow from the left ventricle to the right ventricle, leading to accentuated splitting of S2.
  • Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA): PDA is a condition where a blood vessel called the ductus arteriosus, which connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta during fetal development, remains open after birth. This can result in abnormal blood flow and increased flow across the pulmonary valve, leading to a more pronounced splitting of S2.

The congenital heart disease that does not typically present with split-second heart sounds is: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

Components of Tetralogy of Fallot:

  • Pulmonary Stenosis:
    • Narrowing of the pathway from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery, possibly affecting the infundibulum, valve, or main pulmonary artery.
  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD):
    • A large hole between the right and left ventricles, usually misaligned, allowing abnormal blood flow.
  • Overriding Aorta:
    • The aorta is positioned over the septum, receiving blood from both ventricles.
  • Right Ventricular Hypertrophy:
    • Thickening of the right ventricle wall due to the extra effort required to pump blood.

Examination findings in TOF

Cardiac Auscultation
  • Heart Sounds: Typically normal first heart sound with a single second heart sound (pulmonic component usually inaudible)
  • Murmur: Harsh systolic ejection murmur, crescendo-decrescendo in quality
    • Best heard at the left mid to upper sternal border
    • Radiates posteriorly
    • The severity of the murmur correlates with the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction
    • May occasionally have a regurgitant quality
  • Early systolic click: Sometimes heard along the left sternal border (attributed to flow through a dilated ascending aorta)
  • Continuous murmur: Present over the back and axillary regions in patients with pulmonary atresia and aortopulmonary collaterals

Palpation
  • Prominent ventricular impulse
  • Systolic thrill may be palpable along the left sternal border

questions.text: The given chest x-ray is suggestive of :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tetralogy of Fallot

Explanation:

The given chest X-ray shows boot shaped cardiac silhouette, which is suggestive of cardiac anomaly Tetralogy of Fallot. It is due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex.

Components of Tetralogy of Fallot

  • Pulmonary Stenosis
  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)
  • Overriding Aorta
  • Right Ventricular Hypertrophy

General Clinical Features of TOF

  • Cyanosis
  • Hypercyanotic Spells (Tet Spells)
  • Murmurs.

Treatment of ToF:

  • Management of Tet Spells
    • Immediate interventions:
      • Knee-chest position
      • Oxygen administration
      • Morphine for sedation
      • Intravenous fluids
  • Surgical Repair
    • Complete Repair
      • Procedure: Close VSD, relieve RVOT obstruction
      • Approach: Transatrial-transpulmonary
      • Considerations: Minimizing pulmonary insufficiency with smaller patches
    • Palliative Shunts
      • Blalock-Taussig Shunt: Connects subclavian artery to pulmonary artery
      • Central Shunt: Connects ascending aorta to main pulmonary artery

 

In Atrial septal defect and Ventricular septal defect (Option B and C) typical boot-shaped heart is not seen.

Box-shaped heart seen in Ebstein’s anomaly (Option D)

Named malformation of CVS in chest X ray

Snowman or "figure-of-eight" appearance: seen in Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC)"

Scimitar sign: seen in Partial Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (PAPVC)
 

Box-shaped heart: seen in Ebstein’s anomaly

Gooseneck deformity: seen in

endocardial cushion defects

questions.text: In children diagnosed with congenital heart disease, NADA’s criteria include all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Increased Troponin T

Explanation:

Increased Troponin T (Option B) is not included under NADA’s criteria


Nada’s criteria: (used for clinical diagnosis of congenital heart disease)

 

Major

Minor

Systolic murmur grade III or more

Systolic murmur grade I or II

Diastolic murmur (Option A ruled out)

Abnormal second heart sound

Cyanosis

Abnormal ECG

Congestive cardiac failure (Option D ruled out)

Abnormal X-ray (Option C ruled out)
 

Abnormal Blood pressure


Presence of one major or 2 minor criteria is needed to indicate the presence of CHD.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is responsible for returning deoxygenated blood back to the placenta in fetal circulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Umbilical artery

  • In fetal circulation, deoxygenated blood is carried back to the placenta through the umbilical artery.

Fetal circulation:

Structure

Number

Type of Blood

Flow of blood

Umbilical Artery

2

Deoxygenated blood

Fetus to the placenta

Umbilical Vein

1

Oxygenated blood

Placenta to the fetus

questions.text: Which congenital heart disease exhibits equivalent saturation levels across all heart chambers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

  • The congenital heart disease that exhibits equivalent saturation levels across all heart chambers is total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation.
  • This is because, in this condition, the systemic and pulmonary venous blood mixes in the heart (right atrium) and then is distributed into all chambers of the heart leading to an equivalent saturation across all heart chambers.

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection:

  • Pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly via an abnormal venous connection.

Sites of venous connection:

  • Supracardiac- superior vena cava
  • Cardiac-coronary sinus, right atrium
  • Infracardiac
  • Mixed

Clinical presentation:

  • Cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure

Diagnosis:

  • Chest X-ray:
    • Snowman or figure-8 configuration.
    • Cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascularity are evident
  • ECG: Right axis deviation and right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • Others: Echocardiography, CT, MRI.

Treatment:

  • Supplemental oxygen
  • Ionotropic support
  • Mechanical ventilation if necessary
  • Balloon Atrial Septostomy: This may be required in rare cases with a restricted patent foramen ovale.
  • Cardiac catheterization: Stents may be placed to stabilize the neonate in cases of obstructive TAPVC.

In Tetralogy of Fallot (Option A), there is a ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, pulmonary stenosis and right ventricular hypertrophy. Thus, the failure in the closure of the foramen ovale, right to left results in mixed blood in the left heart and unoxygenated blood in the right heart. Hence all four chambers don't have the same oxygen concentration.

Tricuspid atresia (Option C) is a congenital condition characterised by the absence of the tricuspid valve, leading to a hypoplastic (underdeveloped) right ventricle. Here, blood flows through an atrial septal defect (ASD) into the left atrium (LA) and then to the left ventricle (LV). The saturation cannot be equal across all chambers since the left ventricle is hypoplastic.

In transposition of great arteries (Option D), the right ventricle ends at the right aorta, which carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the tissue while the left ventricle drains into the pulmonary artery. Hence two separate systems are created. Deoxygenated blood is circulated in systemic circulation and oxygenated in the pulmonary circulation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought to her paediatrician for routine well-child care. Her physical examination is normal except for a systolic murmur and a widely split-second heart sound that does not vary with respiration. She has no family history of heart disease. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Atrial septal defect

  • The systolic murmur and a widely split-second heart sound in an otherwise normal child indicate an atrial septal defect.

Atrial septal defect

Pathophysiology:

Feature

Description

Left-to-Right Shunting

Oxygenated blood flows from the left to right atrium; the degree of shunting varies with defect size and vascular resistance.

Right Heart Volume Overload

Increased blood flow causes enlargement of the right atrium and ventricle, and dilation of the pulmonary artery.

Pulmonary Vascular Resistance

May increase with time, after remaining low during childhood, and lead to reversal of shunt and cyanosis.

Clinical Manifestations:

Symptoms

Description

Asymptomatic

Many children are asymptomatic.

Failure to Thrive

Poor growth and weight gain.

Exercise Intolerance

Difficulty with physical activity.

 

Physical Examination Findings:

Finding

Description

Widely Split and Fixed S2

The second heart sound is split and fixed due to increased right ventricular diastolic volume.

Systolic Ejection Murmur

Soft murmur at the left upper sternal border, caused by increased flow across the right ventricular outflow tract.

Mid-Diastolic Murmur

Rumbling murmur at the lower left sternal border due to increased flow across the tricuspid valve.

Children with total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (Option A) are not asymptomatic and often present with cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure with equal saturation levels across all four heart chambers. Examination findings of fixed split S2, systolic ejection murmur, and cyanosis are seen. Hence, it is not the given scenario.

In ventricular septal defects (Option B), there are left-to-right shunts that are symptomatic depending on the size of the defect and may vary from asymptomatic with normal pulmonary artery pressure and a loud, harsh or blowing holosystolic murmur to pulmonary hypertension and symptoms of congestive cardiac failure.

Pulmonary stenosis (Option D) is the narrowing of the pathway from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery, possibly affecting the infundibulum, valve, or main pulmonary artery. It is a component of the Tetralogy of Fallot and often presents with severe cyanosis from birth. The clinical findings include an ejection click heard after S1 (closer to S1 as the severity increases) and a split S2 in moderate to severe cses.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common association with Tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Down’s syndrome

  • The most common association with Tetralogy of Fallot is for Down’s syndrome.
  • Tetralogy of Fallot is also associated with Alagille syndrome and DiGeorge syndrome.

Down's syndrome, caused by trisomy 21, is associated with multiple systemic manifestations due to the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21.

  • This is due to meiotic nondisjunction in either maternal or paternal gamete.
  • Occurs at a frequency of 1:800 to 1:1000 newborns.
  • The overexpression of genes located on chromosome 21 contributes to the clinical features.

Comorbidities associated with Down syndrome:

  • Congenital Heart Disease:
    • 40% of children have congenital heart defects, primarily endocardial cushion defects (40-60% of cases)
    • They are: AVSD, Ventricular Septal Defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Patent Ductus Arteriosus, and Tetralogy Of Fallot.
    • Early cardiac evaluation is crucial.
  • Gastrointestinal Malformations: 12% have atresias, especially duodenal atresia. There is an increased risk of annular pancreas and Hirschsprung disease.
  • Ophthalmic Problems: Increased risk of cataracts, nystagmus, strabismus, and visual acuity issues. Regular eye evaluations are advised from infancy onward.
  • Hearing Defects: 40-60% experience conductive hearing loss, often due to serous otitis media in the first year. Routine hearing assessments are recommended before 6 months of age and annually.
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Hypothyroidism occurs in 13-54% of patients.
  • Atlanto-occipital Subluxation: Incidence ranges from 10-30%. A lateral neck radiograph is recommended.
  • Physical Growth: Linear growth is typically slower, and children may become obese with age. Muscle tone often improves, but regular monitoring of height and weight is necessary.
  • Malignancies: Increased risk of lymphoproliferative disorders, such as acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, acute myeloid leukaemia, myelodysplasia, and transient lymphoproliferative syndrome.
  • Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease: The APP gene, located on chromosome 21, plays a significant role in amyloid plaque formation, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.

Klinefelter syndrome (Option A) involves mitral valve prolapse, ASD, partial atrioventricular canal defect, and patent ductus arteriosus.
Edwards syndrome (Option B) (trisomy 18) involves ventricular septal defect (VSD), patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), and polyvalvular dysplasia.
In Turner’s syndrome (Option D), the cardiac abnormalities seen are coarctation of the Aorta and bicuspid aortic valve. TOF is not a part of this condition.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents for an antenatal check-up and is currently on lithium for her bipolar disorder. This drug must be stopped, due to the risk of development of which of the following conditions in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Ebstein anomaly

  • Lithium intake by the pregnant mother can cause Ebstein anomaly in the fetus.

Ebstein's Anomaly:

  • Associated with lithium exposure during pregnancy.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Downward displacement/prolapse of the tricuspid valve.
    • Part of the right ventricular volume becomes part of the right atrium (atrialization of the right ventricle).
  • Consequences:
    • Tricuspid Regurgitation: Prolapsed valve → Blood from the right ventricle regurgitates into the right atrium.
    • RVOT (Right Ventricular Outflow Tract) Obstruction: Prolapsed valve partly occludes blood flow towards the pulmonary artery → Cyanosis.
  • Features:
    • Cyanosis at birth or during the neonatal period.
    • Pansystolic murmur: Due to tricuspid regurgitation.
    • Quadruple Rhythm: Irregular blood flow in the right heart, RVOT obstruction, and tricuspid regurgitation → Multiple added sounds and ejection clicks.
  • X-Ray Findings:
    • Right atrial enlargement due to regurgitation from the right ventricle and atrialization of the right ventricle.
    • RA forms the right heart border, which displaces laterally and appears on X-ray as a box-shaped heart.
  • ECG: Himalayan P Waves

VACTERL (Option B) is a broad spectrum of congenital anomalies including vertebral anomalies, anorectal anomalies (anal atresia), cardiac anomalies, tracheoesophageal fistula or atresia, renal anomalies, and limb anomalies. Lithium is not a cause of this condition.

Coarctation of the Aorta (Option C): Varying degrees of coarctation occur at any point from the transverse arch to the iliac bifurcation. It is associated with Kabuki syndrome and Turner syndrome. It is not associated with Lithium exposure.

Supravalvular aortic stenosis (Option D) is a type of acyanotic congenital heart disease associated with William’s syndrome and is not associated with lithium exposure.

questions.text:
An unconscious child is brought to the casualty. What is the correct sequence of the management?


	Assess breathing
	Assess pulse
	Assess response
	Start compressions
	Bag and mask ventilation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 3-1-2-4-5

 

Explanation:

 

This question follows the Paediatric Basic Life Support (BLS) algorithm. The correct sequence is as follows:

  1. Assess response (Option 3):

    • First, check if the child is responsive by tapping and shouting. If unresponsive, shout for help and proceed to airway and breathing assessment.

  2. Assess breathing (Option 1):

    • Open the airway using head-tilt chin-lift or jaw thrust and check for normal breathing for no more than 10 seconds.

  3. Assess pulse (Option 2):

    • Check the central pulse (carotid or femoral). If no pulse or pulse <60 bpm with signs of poor perfusion, start chest compressions.

  4. Start compressions (Option 4):

    • Begin high-quality CPR with a compression rate of 100–120/min and depth of 1/3rd chest diameter.

  5. Bag and mask ventilation (Option 5):

    • Provide ventilations using a bag-valve-mask (if trained and equipment is available) or continue with rescue breaths if no equipment.

 

Steps in Basic Life Support Skills:

questions.text:
Which of the following cyanotic heart diseases causes increased pulmonary blood flow?


	Ebstein anomaly
	Tetralogy of Fallot
	Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
	Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC)
questions.solution:
Cyanotic heart diseases with increased pulmonary blood flow are seen in transposition of the great arteries (TGA) and total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC).

 

Pulmonary Blood Flow in Congenital Heart Diseases (CHD):

Decreased Pulmonary Blood Flow

(Normal Pulmonary Artery Pressure)

Increased Pulmonary Blood Flow

(with Pulmonary Artery Hypertension)

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) (2)

Persistent Truncus Arteriosus

Double Outlet Right Ventricle (DORV) with VSD and Pulmonary Stenosis (PS)

Double Outlet Right Ventricle (DORV) with VSD

Tricuspid Atresia with VSD and PS

Tricuspid Atresia with Large VSD

Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD) with PS

Non-Obstructive Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC) (4)

Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) with Congenitally Corrected Transposition (CCT) and PS

Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) (3): Simple or with Large VSD/PDA

Single Ventricle with PS

Single Ventricle

Other Univentricular Hearts with PS

Other Univentricular Hearts with PAH

Ebstein's Anomaly (1)

questions.text:
Nada's Minor Criteria include


	Systolic murmur Grade 3
	Diastolic murmur
	Abnormal second heart sound
	Abnormal BP
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 3 and 4

Explanation:

  • Nada's criteria is a diagnostic tool used to identify congenital heart disease (CHD) in children.
  • Nada's Criteria for Congenital Heart Disease
  • Presence of one major criterion or two minor criteria suggests the likelihood of CHD.

 

Major Criteria

Minor Criteria

Systolic murmur of Grade 3 or more

Systolic murmur less than Grade 3

Any diastolic murmur

Abnormal second heart sound (S2)

Cyanosis

Abnormal ECG

Congestive cardiac failure

Abnormal chest X-ray findings

Abnormal blood pressure (BP)

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis for a newborn exhibiting weak lower limb pulses and strong upper limb pulses?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) COA

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Coarctation of Aorta (COA), a congenital narrowing of the aorta typically occurring just distal to the left subclavian artery at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus.
  • Coarctation of the Aorta is characterized by weak femoral pulses (lower limb pulses) and strong upper limb pulses. There is a disparity in pulsation and BP in the arms and legs. This is referred to as Radio-femoral delay.

Coarctation of the Aorta

Definition
  • Constrictions of the aorta of varying degrees at any point from the transverse arch to the iliac bifurcation.

Clinical presentation:
  • Differential cyanosis
  • Heart failure in severe cases
  • Weakness or pain/claudication (or both) in the legs after exercise
  • Radio-femoral delay: Disparity in pulsation and BP in the arms and legs
  • Systolic or continuous murmurs are heard over the left and right sides of the chest laterally and posteriorly due to collateral blood flow.

Investigation:
  • Chest x-ray:
  • The arrows indicate rib notching and the yellow line shows the site of coarctation
  • Enlarged left subclavian artery produces a prominent shadow in the left superior mediastinum.
  • Notching of the inferior border of the ribs from pressure erosion by enlarged collateral vessels (Common in late childhood after 1st decade of life)
  • Descending aorta has an area of post-stenotic dilation.
  • ECG, echocardiography, colour Doppler, CT, and MRI.

Treatment:
  • Infusion of prostaglandin E1 to reopen the ductus and reestablish adequate lower-extremity blood flow.
  • Surgical repair

Incorrect Options:

Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA) (Option A) is a congenital heart defect where the aorta arises from the right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle. It presents with early cyanosis and circulatory compromise but does not typically cause differential pulses between the upper and lower extremities.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) (Option C): While TOF causes cyanosis and may have associated heart failure, it does not cause differential pulses between the upper and lower extremities. TOF is characterized by ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, pulmonary stenosis and right ventricular hypertrophy.

Ebstein anomaly (Option D): This condition involves abnormal positioning of the tricuspid valve and right heart dysfunction but does not cause differential pulses.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with stable vitals and an ECG showing paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Which of the following is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Adenosine 0.1 mg/kg:

  • This is the correct initial treatment for PSVT in a child with stable vitals. Adenosine is a first-line medication for terminating PSVT by temporarily blocking the AV node, often restoring normal sinus rhythm.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cardioversion:

  • This is typically reserved for patients with PSVT who are hemodynamically unstable or in cases where pharmacologic treatment is ineffective. Given that the child has stable vitals, cardioversion is not the first-line treatment.

Option B - Adenosine 0.2 mg/kg:

  • This is the dose used if the initial dose of adenosine (0.1 mg/kg) fails to convert the PSVT. It is not the starting dose, so it is not the appropriate initial treatment.

Option D - IV Adrenaline:

  • Adrenaline is not indicated for treating PSVT. It is used in resuscitation protocols, particularly in cases of cardiac arrest or anaphylaxis, not for stable PSVT.

questions.text: What is the most common defect in a ventricular septal defect?

choices.text: Non-development of the perimembranous part of the septum

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Membranous defect

Explanation

The most common defect in ventricular septal defect (VSD) is membranous defect.

Pathophysiology of VSD:

  • The interventricular septum has two parts: membranous and muscular.
  • VSD occurs due to incomplete development or fusion of septal components during embryonic cardiac formation.
  • A unified classification system is used to describe VSDs.

Types of VSD:

  • Infundibular (Outlet) VSD:
    • Location: Below semilunar valves (aortic and pulmonary), within the outlet septum of the right ventricle.
       
  • Perimembranous VSD:
    • Location: Membranous septum, below crista supraventricularis.
    • Characteristics: Most common (80% of cases), may involve muscular septum, potential for spontaneous closure.
       
  • Inlet (Atrioventricular Canal) VSD:
    • Location: Below the inlet valves (tricuspid and mitral), in the inlet portion of the right ventricle septum.
    • Characteristics: Represents 8% of all VSDs, more common in patients with Trisomy 21.
       
  • Muscular (Trabecular) VSD:
    • Location: Muscular septum (apical, central, outlet regions).
    • Characteristics: Can present as multiple defects ("Swiss cheese"), more common in infants, the tendency to close spontaneously with age.

Gerbode Defects:

  • A distinct defect with a direct connection between the left ventricle and right atrium.
  • Type 1: True Gerbode, congenital deficiency in the membranous septum.
  • Type 2: Subvalvular type, ventriculo-atrial shunting due to central VSD and tricuspid valve defect.
  • Type 3: Combination of Type 1 and Type 2 characteristics.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of the closure of ductus arteriosus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Increase in Oxygen

 

Explanation:

An increase in oxygen concentration increases the constriction of the smooth muscles of ductus arteriosus, leading to the closure of it. Ductus arteriosus is a structure connecting the aorta and pulmonary artery in fetal circulation ,which closes after delivery of the fetus.

 

Changes in Fetal Circulation Following Birth:

 

Parameter/Structure

Change

Cause

Pulmonary Vascular Resistance (PVR)

Decreases

(Option C)

Mechanical expansion of the lungs and increased arterial PO2 lead to a rapid decrease in PVR.

Systemic Vascular Resistance (SVR)

Increases

The removal of the low-resistance placental circulation results in an increase in SVR.

Ductus Arteriosus Shunt

Reverses and eventually closes.

As PVR becomes lower than SVR, the shunt through the ductus arteriosus reverses from right-to-left to left-to-right.

High arterial PO2 leads to the constriction and eventual closure of the ductus arteriosus, which later becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

Foramen Ovale

Closes

Increased pulmonary blood flow to the left atrium raises left atrial volume and pressure, leading to the functional closure of the foramen ovale.

Ductus Venosus

Closes

The removal of the placenta from circulation results in the closure of the ductus venosus.

Left ventricular Wall Thickness and Mass

Increases

The left ventricle's wall thickness and mass increase as it adapts to the high-resistance systemic circulation.

Right ventricular Wall Thickness and Mass

Decreases


 

The right ventricle's wall thickness and mass decrease as it adapts to the low-resistance pulmonary circulation.

Left Ventricular Output

Increases

The left ventricle now must deliver the entire systemic cardiac output, which is almost a 200% increase compared to fetal conditions.

Right Ventricular Output

Increases

Opening of pulmonary vasculature results in increased right ventricular output.

 

Time frame of closure of shunts following birth:

Shunt

Functional Closure

Anatomical closure

Remnant

Ductus Arteriosus

10-15 hrs after birth

2 -3 weeks after birth

Ligamentum arteriosum

Foramen ovale

3rd month

1 year after birth

Fossa ovalis

Ductus venosus

Immediately after birth

3-7 days after birth

Ligamentum venosum.

 

  • CO2 and catecholamines have no role in ductal closure (Option B, D).

questions.text: A professor explains the pathophysiology of a “tet spell” and that it is due to a decrease in systemic vascular resistance that leads to more shunting of blood from right to left, causing an overload on the left side of the heart and decreasing the amount of blood reaching the lungs. Which of the following options determines the severity of the cyanotic spells?

choices.text: Size of the ventricular septal defect (VSD)

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Degree of pulmonary stenosis:

  • Tet spells, also called hypercyanotic spells, are characteristic features of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).
  • During a tet spell, there is an increased right-to-left shunting of blood, leading to decreased oxygenation and cyanosis.
  • The severity of these spells is influenced by the degree of pulmonary stenosis, which refers to the narrowing of the pulmonary valve or the pulmonary artery.
  • Increased pulmonary stenosis results in more restricted blood flow to the lungs, exacerbating the right-to-left shunting and worsening the severity of the cyanotic spells.


Incorrect options: Options A, B, and C do not determine the severity of the cyanotic spells. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What is the most common congenital defect observed in individuals with Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Atrioventricular septal defect:

  • The atrioventricular septal defect is a congenital cardiac malformation that is characterized by a variable degree of the atrial and ventricular septal defect along with a common or partially separate atrioventricular orifice..
  • AVSD is the most common congenital heart defect associated with Down's syndrome.


Incorrect options - A, B, and D are not the most common congenital defect observed in individuals with Down syndrome.

questions.text: What is the primary factor for the closure of the ductus arteriosus after birth?

choices.text: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2)

questions.solution:
Correct option A- Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2).

  • The main factor for ductal closure postnatally is an increase in the partial pressure of oxygen in the blood.
  • When a newborn transitions from the intrauterine environment to the outside world, there is a sudden increase in the oxygen concentration due to the initiation of lung ventilation.
  • This increased oxygen tension acts as a stimulus for the closure of the ductus arteriosus.

Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not the factors for the closure of the ductus arteriosus after birth.

questions.text: Which of the following choices best characterizes the chest X-ray picture?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Coeur en sabot:

  • Coeur en sabot, or "boot-shaped heart," refers to a characteristic appearance of the heart on a chest X-ray.
  • It appears elongated and narrowed at the base, resembling the shape of a boot.
  • This is typically associated with congenital heart defects such as Tetralogy of Fallot.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Egg on string appearance: 

  • Egg on a string appearance is seen in a condition called Transposition of the Great Arteries.

​​​​​​​Option C: Scimitar sign:

  • The scimitar sign is seen in a condition called Scimitar syndrome, where a pulmonary vein from the right lung drains into the inferior vena cava instead of the left atrium.
  • This creates a characteristic curved appearance on the X-ray resembling a scimitar, a type of curved sword.

Option D - Snowman sign:

  • The snowman sign refers to the appearance of the pulmonary artery and its branches on a chest X-ray in certain conditions, such as pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect.
  • It appears as a "snowman" shape with the main pulmonary artery and its branches resembling the head and body of a snowman.

questions.text:
Please match the appropriate answers related to cardiac abnormalities and their corresponding syndromes.


	
		
			
			1) Noonan syndrome
			
			
			(A) PDA
			
		
		
			
			2) Downs syndrome
			
			
			(B) Bicuspid aortic valve
			
		
		
			
			3) Turner syndrome
			
			
			(C) Endocardial cushion defects
			
		
		
			
			4) Congenital Rubella Syndrome
			
			
			(D) Pulmonary stenosis
questions.solution:
Correct option B- 1-(D), 2-(C), 3-(B), 4-(A):

 

Congenital syndromes

Cardiac abnormalities

Noonan syndrome

Pulmonary stenosis

Down syndrome

Endocardial cushion defects

Turner syndrome

Bicuspid aortic valve

Congenital rubella syndrome

PDA

questions.text: Continuous murmur is heard in:
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Patent ductus arteriosus:

  • A continuous murmur refers to a murmur that is heard throughout systole and diastole without interruption.
  • Continuous murmur is heard in patent ductus arteriosus
  • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a congenital heart defect characterized by the persistence of a normal fetal connection between the pulmonary artery and the aorta, known as the ductus arteriosus.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B: Ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSD produces a holosystolic murmur.

Option C: Atrial septal defect (ASD): ASD typically causes a systolic ejection murmur.

Option D: Tetralogy of Fallot: Tetralogy of Fallot is associated with a systolic ejection murmur, often described as a harsh or crescendo-decrescendo murmur.
